And the Cats cryes, mew, mew mew,
And still the Cats cryes mew, mew, mew.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I shall be mowz'd by pusse-cattes: but I had rather dye a dogs death; they haue nine liues (a peece like a woman) and they will make it vp ten liues, if they and I fall a scratching: Bright Helena of this house, wod thy Troy were a fire, for I am a colde; or else wod I had the Greekes wodden Curtall, to ride away: most Ambrosian-lipt creature, come away quicklie, for this nights lodging lyes colde at my heart.
The Spanish Pauin: I thought the deuill could not vnderstand Spanish: but since thou art my countriman, ô thou tawnie Satin, I will daunce after thy pipe.
sp.l: He daunces the Spanish Pauin.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Ho sweet deuill, ho thou wilt make any man weary of thee, tho he deale with thee in his shirt,
sp.l: Sweet beautie; shee'll not come, Ile fall to sleepe,
And dreame of her, loue-dreames are nere too deepe.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Ho, ho, Frisco, Madona, I am in hell, but heer is no fire; Hell fire is all put out; what ho? so ho ho? I shall bee drown'd; I beseech thee, deare Frisco, raise Blurt the Constable, or some Scauinger, to come and make cleane these kennels of hell, for they stinke so, that I shall cast away my precious selfe.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Is he downe Frisco?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hee's downe, he cryes out he's in hell, it's heauen to me to haue him cry so.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fye, fye, fye, let him lye, and get all to bed.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Not all, I haue fatting knauerie in hand,
He cryes he's damn'd in hell; the next shall cry,
Hee's clyming vp to heauen, and heer's the ginne:
One woodcocke 'staine, Ile haue his brother in.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Briske as a capring Taylor; I was washt,
But did they shaue me? noh, I am too wise;
Lye close i'th bosome of their knaueries,
I am an olde hoarie Courtier, and strike dead:
I hit my markes: ware, ware, a perelous head.
Cast, I must finde a ladder made of roapes,
Ladder and roape, what follow? hanging;
But where? ah ha, there does the riddle lye.
I haue scapt drowning; but, but, but, I hope,
I shall not scape the ladder and the roape.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Yonder's a light Master Constable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Peace woodcocke the sconce approaches.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Whew:

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I, whisling? Slubber Iog the watch, & giue the Lanthorne a flap.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Whew, Symp, Symperina?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Signior Curuetto heer's the ladder, I watch to doe you a good turne, I am Frisco, is not Blurt abroad and his Bill-men?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No matter if they be, I heare none nye:
I will snug close; out goes my candles eye,
My sconce takes this in snuffe, all's one I care not.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Why when?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I come, close, close, holde rope and spare not.

sp.speaker: Slu.
sp.l: Now the candle's out.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Frisco, light, light, my foote is slipt, call helpe:

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, helpe, theeues, theeues, helpe, theeues, &c.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Theeues, where? follow close: Slubber the Lanthorne, holde; I charge you in the Dukes name stand: Sirra, y'are like to hang for this: downe with him.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Master Blurt, Master Constable, heer's his ladder, hee comes to rob my mistris, I haue bin scar'd out of my wits, aboue seauen times by him, and it's fortie to one, if euer they come in agen, I lay fellonie to his charge.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Fellonie? you cunny-catching slaue.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Cunny-catching will beare an action; Ile cunny-catch you for this; if I can finde our key I will ayde you: Master Blurt, if not, looke to him, as you will answere it vpon your death-bed.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A Venetian Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Woodcocke, how dost thou Woodcocke?

sp.speaker: Wod.
sp.l: Thanke your worship.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Woodcocke, you are of our side now, and therfore your acquaintance cannot serue, and you were a Gentleman of veluet I would commit you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Why, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: What am I sir? doe not you know this staffe? I am sir the Dukes owne Image; at this time the Dukes tongue (for fault of a better) lyes in my mouth; I am Constable sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Constable, and commit me? marie Blurt Master Constable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: It's follie to striue,

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: I say awaie with him, Ile Blurt you, Ile teach you to stand couer'd to Authoritie; your hoarie head shall bee knockt when this staffe is in place.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I but Master Constable—

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: No, pardon me, you abuse the Duke, in me that am his Cipher, I say away with him; Gulch, away with him; Woodcocke, keepe you with me, I wil be known for more then Blurt.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Thou honest fellow (the man in the Moone) I beseech thee set fire on thy bush of thornes, to light and warme me, for I am dung wet: I fell like Lucifer I thinke into hell, and am crauld out, but in worse pickle than my leane Pilcher: heere about is the Hot-house of my loue, ho, ho? why ho there?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Who's that? what Deuill standes hohing at my doore so late?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I beseech thee Frisco take in Lazarilloes ghost.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Lazarilloes ghost? haunt me not I charge thee, I knowe thee not, I am in a dreame of a drie-Summer, therefore appeare not to me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is not this the mantion of the cherrie-lipt Madona Imperia?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Yes, how than? you Fly-blowne rascall, what art thou?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Lazarilla de Tormes: sweete bloud, I haue a poore Spanish suite, depending in your house; let me enter most pretious Frisco, the Mistris of this mansion is my beautifull Hoastesse.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: How? you Turpentine pill, my wife your Hostesse? away you Spanish vermine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I beseech thee (most pittifull Frisco) allow my lamentation.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And you lament heere, Ile stone you with Brick-bats, I am a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: My Slop and Mandillion lye at thy mercy (fine Frisco) I beseech thee let not my case bee thine, I must and will lament.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Must you? Ile wash off your teares; away you hogs-face.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou hast sowsed my poor hogs-face: O Frisco, thou art a scuruie Doctor, to cast my water no better; it is most rammish Vrine, Mars shall not saue thee, I will make a browne toaste of thy heart, and drinke it in a pot of thy strong bloud.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt and all his watch.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Such fellows must be taken downe, stand: what white thing is yonder?

sp.speaker: Slub.
sp.l: Who goes there? come before the Constable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My deare hoast Blurt:

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: You haue Blurted faire, I am by my Office to examine you, where you haue spent these two nights?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Most bigge Blurt, I answere thy great Authoritie, that I haue beene in hell, and am scratcht to death with Pusse-Cattes.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Doe you run a'th score at an Officers house, & then runne aboue twelue score off?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I did not runne my sweet-fac'd Blurt; the Spanish fleete is bringing golde enough to discharge all, from the Indies: lodge
me most pittifull Bill-man.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Marie and will: I am (in the Dukes name) to charge you with despicious of fellonie: and Burglarie is committed this night, and we are to reprehend any that we thinke to bee faultie; were not you at Madona freckle-faces house?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Signior sec.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Away with him, clap him vp.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Most thundring Blurt doe not clap me,
Most thundring Blurt doe not clap me.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Master Lazarus, I know you are a sore fellow where you take, and therefore I charge you (in the Dukes name) to goe without wrasling, though you be in your shirt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Commendable Blurt.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: The end of my comendations is to commit you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am kin to Don Dego the Spanish Adelantado.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: If you he kin to Don Dego (that was smelt out in Paules) you packe; your Lantedoes nor your Lanteeroes cannot serue your turne: I charge you, let me commit you to the tuition.—

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Worshipfull Blurt, doe not commit me into the hands of dogs.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Dogs?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Master Lazarus, ther's not a dog shall bite you, these are true Bill-men, that fight vnder the common wealthes flag.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Blurt—

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Blurt me no Blurts, Ile teach all Spaniards how to meddle with whoores.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Most cunning Constable, all Spaniards know that alreadie, I haue medled with none.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Your being in your shirt berayes you.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I beseech thee most honest Blurt, let not my shirt beraye me.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p:
I say away with him: Musicke, that's in the Curtizans; they are about some vngodlie Acte, but Ile play a part in't ere
morning: away with Lazarus.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Come Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: Thy kytes and thee, for this shal watch in durt to feede on carrion.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Hence, ptrooh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O base Blurt! O base Blurt! O base Blurt!
sp.stage: Enter Camillo, Hippolito, Virgilio, Asorino, Baptista, Bentiuoli Doyt and Dandyprat, all weapon'd, their Rapiers sheathes in their hands.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Noble Italians, whome I loue best; who know best what wrongs I haue stood vnder: being lay de on by him, who is to thanke me for his life, I did bestowe him (as the prize of mine honour) vpon my Loue, the most faire Violetta: my loues merit was basely solde to him, by the most false Violetta: not content with this Fellonie, he hath dar'd to adde the sweet theft of Ignoble marriage; shee's now, nones but his, and hee (treacherous villaine) any ones, but hers; hee dotes (my honor'd friends) on a painted Curtizan, and in scorne of our Italian lawes, our familie, our reuenge, loathes Violettaes bed, for a harlots bosome: I coniure you therefore, by all the bonds of Gentilitie, that as you haue solemnely sworne a most sharpe; so let the reuenge be most sodaine.

sp.speaker: Uir.
sp.l: Be not your selfe a barre, to that sodainnes, by this protraction.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Away Gentlemen, away then.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: As for that light Hobby-horse my Sister, whose foule name, I will race out with my Poniard; by the honour of my Familie (which her lust hath prophaned) I sweare (and Gentlemen be in this, my sworne brothers) I sweare that as all Uenice does admire her beautie, so all the world shall be amazed at her punishment, follow therefore.

sp.speaker: Uir.
sp.p: Stay, let our resolutions keepe together: whether goe; we first?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To the Strumpet Imperiaes.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, what then?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There to finde Fontinell; found, to kill him.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And kill'd, to hang out his reeking bodie, at his Harlots window.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And by his body, the strumpets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And betweene both, my Sisters.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The Tragedie is iust: on then, begin.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: As you goe, euerie hand pull in a friend, to strengthen vs against all opposites: he that has any drop of true Italian bloud in him, thus vow (this morning) to shed others, or let out his owne; if you consent to this, follow me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Via, away, the treacherous Frenchman dyes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: At so, Saint Marke my Pistoll, thus death flyes.
sp.stage: Enter Fontinell and Imperia arme in arme.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ah you little effeminate sweete Cheueleere, why dost thou not get a loose Periwig of haire on thy chinne, to set thy French face off, by the panting pulse of Uenus: thou art welcome a thousand degrees beyond the reach of Arithmaticke: Good, good, good, your lip is moiste & moouing; it hath the truest French close, euen like Mapew; la, la, la &c.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Deare Ladie, ô life of loue, what sweetnes dwels
In loues varietie? the soule that plods
In one harsh booke of beautie; but repeates
The stale and tedious learning, that hath oft
Faded the sences: when (in reading more)
We glide in new sweets, and are staru'd with store,
Now by the heart of loue, my Uiolet
Is a foule weede (ô pure Italian flower!)
She, a blacke Negro, to the white compare,
Of this vnequal'd beautie: O most accurst!
That I haue giuen her leaue to challenge me:
But Ladie, poison speakes Italian well,
And in a loathed kisse, Ile include her hell.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so doe, doe, doe, come, come, come; will you condemne the mute rushes to be prest to death by your sweet body? downe, downe, downe, heere, heere, heere; leane your head vpon the lap of my gowne; good, good good: O Saint Marke! Heere is a loue-marke able to weare more Ladies eyes for Iewels then— oh! lye still, lye still, I will leuill a true Venetian kisse ouer your right shoulder.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Shoote home (faire Mistris) and as that kisse flyes,
From lip to lip, wound me with your sharpe eyes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: No, no, no, Ile beate this Cherry-tree thus, & thus, and thus; and you name wound.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: I will offend so, to be beaten still.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Doe, doe, doe, and if you make any more such lips, when I beate you, by my Virginitie you shall busse this rod: Musicke: I pray thee bee not a puritaine. Sister to the rest of the Sciences, I knewe the time when thou couldst abide handling.
Oh, fie, fie, fie, forbeare, thou art like a punie-Barber (new come to the trade) thou pick'st our eares too deepe: So, so, so, will my sweet prisoner entertaine a poore Italian Song?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: O most willingly my deare Madona.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I care not if I perswade my bad voice to wrastle with this Musicke and catch a straine; so, so, so, keep time, keep time, keepe time.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Loue for such a cherrie lip,
Would be glad to pawne his arrows:
Venus heere to take a Sip,
Would sell her Doues and teeme of Sparrow.
But they shall not so,
Hey nony nony no:
None but I this lip must owe,
Hey nony nony no.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Your voice does teach the Musicke,

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: Againe, deare Loue.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hey nony nony no:
Did Ioue see this wanton eye,
Ganimede must waite no longer:
Phoebe heere one night did lye,
Would change her face and looke much younger.
But they shall not so,
Hey nony nony no:
None but I this lip must owe,
Hey nony nony no.
sp.stage: Enter Frisco, Triuia, and Simperina running.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: O Madona! Mistris! Madona!

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Case vp this Gentleman, ther's rapping at doore; and one in a small voice, saies, ther's Camilla and Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Simp
sp.l: And they will come in.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Vpon their deathes they shall, for they seeke mine.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: No, no, no, locke the doores fast, Triuia, Simperina, stir.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Come they in shape of Deuils, this Angell by:
I am arm'd, let them come in; vds foote, they dye.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, I will not haue thy white body—

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: What ho; Madona?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: O harke! not hurt for the Rialta; goe, goe, goe, put vp: by my Virginitie you shall put vp.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Heere are Camilla and Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.p:
Into that little roome, you are there as safe as in France, or
the Low Countries.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Oh God!

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: So, so, so, let them enter; Triuia, Simperina, smooth my gowne, treade downe the rushes, let them enter; doe, doe, doe, no wordes pretty darling: la, la, la, hey nony nony no.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Are two men transform'd into one woman?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: How now? what motion's this?

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.p: By your leaue sweet beautie, pardon my excuse, which vnder the maske of Camilloes and my brothers names, sought entrance into this house: good Sweetnes, haue you not a propertie heere, improper to your house, my husband?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Hah; your husband heere?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Nay be as you seeme to be (white Doue) without gall.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Gall? your husband? ha, ha, ha; by my ventoy (yellow Lady) you take your marke improper, no, no, no, my Suger-candie Mistris) your good man is not heere I assure you; heere? ha hah.

sp.speaker: Triu. & Sim.
sp.l: Heere?

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.l: Much husbands heere.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Doe not mocke mee fairest Venetian; come, I knowe hee's heere: good faith I doe not blame him, for your beautie glides ouer his error; troth I am right glad that you (my Countrie woman) haue receiued the pawne of my affections: you cannot bee hard-harted, louing him, nor hate mee, for I loue him too: since wee both loue him, let vs not leaue him, till wee haue call'd home the ill husbandrie of a sweete Stragler; prethee (good wench) vse him well.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p:
If he deserue not to bee vsed well (as Ide bee loath he should deserue it) Ile ingage my selfe (deere beauty) to thine honest hart; giue me leaue to loue him, and Ile giue him a kinde of leaue to loue thee: I know he heer's me; I prethee try mine eyes,
if they knowe him, that haue almost drown'd themselues in their owne salt water, because they cannot see him: In troth Ile not chide him; if I speake wordes rougher then soft kisses, my pennaunce shall bee to see him kisse thee, yet to holde my peace.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: And that's torment enough, alas poore wench.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Shee's an Asse, by the crowne of my Mayden-head,
Ide scratch her eyes out, if my man stood in her Tables.

sp.speaker: Uiol.
sp.l: Good partener, lodge me in thy priuate bed,
Where (in supposed follie) he may end,
Determin'd sinne; thou smil'st, I know thou wilt;
What loosenes may terme dotage (truelie read)
Is loue ripe gather'd, not soone withered.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Good troth (pretty wed-locke) thou makst my little eyes smart, with washing themselues in brine; I keep your Cocke from his owne roost? and mar such a sweete face? and wipe off that daintie red? and make Cupid tole the bell for your loue-sicke hart no, no, no, if he were Ioues own Ingle (Ganimed) fie, fie, fie, Ile none; your Chamber-fellow is within, thou shalt inioy my bed, and thine owne pleasure this night: Simperina conduct in this Ladie; Frisco silence, ha, ha, ha; I am sorrie to see a woman so tame a foole; come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Starre of Venetian beautie, thankes; ô who
Can beare this wrong, and be a woman too?
sp.stage: Enter Camillo, Hippolito, Virgilio and others: the Duke & Gentlemen with him: Blurt and his watch on his side, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are dishonour'd, giue vs way, he dyes, he dyes.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I charge you by your dueties to the State,
And loue to gentrie, sheath your weapons.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Stand, I charge you put vp your naked weapons, and wee'll put vp our rusty Billes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Vp to the hilts, we will in his French bodie.
My Lord, we charge you by the rauisht honour
Of an Italian Lady: by our wrongs,
By that eternall blot (which if this slaue
Passe free without reuenge) like Leprosie,
Will run ouer all the bodie of our fames;
Giue open way to our iust wrath, least bar'd—

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Breaking the bonds of honour and of duetie;
We cut a passage through you with our swoords.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: He that withstands vs, run him through.

sp.speaker: Blurt.
sp.p: I charge you i'th Dukes name (before his owne face) to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Keepe thou the peace, that hast a Peasants heart.

sp.speaker: Watc.
sp.l: Peasant?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Our peace must haue her cheekes painted with bloud.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away, through—

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Sweet Gentlemen: though you haue called the Dukes owne ghost Peasant, for I walke for him i'th night: (Kilderkin & Pisse-breech holde out) yet heere me, (deare blouds) the Duke heere for fault of a better and my selfe; (Cuckoe flye not hence) for fault of a better, are to lay you by the heeles, if you goe thus with fire and swoord; for the Duke is the head, and I Blurt, am the purtenaunce: Woodcocke keepe by my side: Now sir—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A plague vpon this Woodcocke; kill the Watch.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now in the name of manhood I coniure yee,
Appeare in your true shapes; Italians,
You kill your honours more in this reuenge,
Than in his murder: Stay, stand, heer's the house.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Right Sir, this is the whoore-house, heere hee calles and sets in his staffe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Sheath all your weapons worthy Gentlemen,
And by my life I sweare, if Fontinell
Haue stain'd the honour of your Sisters bed,
The fact being death, Ile pay you his proude head,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Arrest him then before our eyes; and see!
Our furie sleepes.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This honest Officer—

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.l: Blurt sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Shall fetch him foorth: goe sirra, in our name
Attach the French Lord.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.l: Garlicke and the rest follow stronglie.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: O what a scandall were it to a State,
To haue a stranger, (and a prisoner)
Murdred by such a troope? Besides, through Uenice
Are numbers of his Country-men dispearst;
Whose rage (meeting with yours) none can preuent
The mischiefe of a bloudie consequent.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt and watch, holding Fontinell and his weapons.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: The Duke is within an Inch of your nose, and therefore
I dare play with it, if you put not vp; deliuer I aduise you.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Yeeld vp my weapons and my foe so nye?
My selfe and weapons shall together yeeld,
Come any one, come all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Kill, kill the Frenchman, kill him.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be satisfi'd my noble Countrymen,
Ile trust you with his life, so you will pawne
The faithes of Gentlemen, no desperate hand
Shall rob him of it; otherwise, he runnes
Vpon this daungerous point, that dares appose
His rage gainst our authoritie: French Lord,
Yeeld vp this strength, our word shal be your Guard.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Who defyes death, needs none, hee's well prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My honest fellow, with a good defence,
Enter againe, fetch out the Curtizan,
And all that are within.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Ile tickle her; it shall nere bee said that a browne Byll lookt pale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Frenchman, thou art indebted to our Duke.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thy life, for (but for him) thy soule
Had long ere this hung trembling in the ayre,
Being frighted from thy bosome with our swoords.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: I doe not thanke your Duke; yet (if you will)
Turne bloudie Executioners: who dyes
For so bright beauty, is a bright Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The beautie you adore so, is prophane,
The breach of wedlocke (by our law) is death.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: Law giue me law.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: With all seueritie.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: In my Loues eyes immortall ioyes doe dwell,
She is my heauen; she from me, I am in hell:
Therefore your Law, your Law:

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Make way, she comes.
sp.stage: Enter Blurt leading Imperia, watch with Violetta maskt.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.l: Fye, Fye, Fye.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Your fye, fye, fye, nor your foh, foh, foh, cannot serue your turne; on must now beare it off with head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now fetch Curuetto, and the Spaniard heather,
Their punishments shall lye vnder one doome,
What is she maskt?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: A puncke too; follow fellows, Slubber afore:

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Shee that is maskt, is leader of this Maske,
What's heere? Bowes, Billes and Gunnes? noble Camillo,
I am sure you are Lord of all this mis-rule: I pray
For whose sake doe you make this swaggering fray?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: For yours, and for your owne we come resolu'd,
To murther him, that poisons your chaste bed;
To take reuenge on you, for your false heart:
And (wanton dame) our wrath heere must not sleepe,
Your sinne being deep'st, your share shall be most deepe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: With pardon of your grace, my selfe (to you all)
At your owne weapons, thus doe answere all.
For paying away my heart, that was my owne,
Fight not to win that, in good troth tis gone,
For my deere loues abusing my chaste bed,
And her sweet theft: Alacke, you are misled,
This was a plot of mine, onelie to trie
Your loues strange temper; sooth I doe not lye.
My Fontinell nere dally'd in her armes;
She neuer bound his heart with amorous charmes,
My Fontinell nere loath'd my sweet embrace,
Shee neuer drew loues picture by his face;
When he from her white hand would striue to goe,
Shee neuer cry'd fye, fye, nor no, no, no.
With prayers and bribes, we hyred her (Both) to lye
Vnder that roofe; for this must my loue dye?
Who dare be so hard harted? looke you, we kisse,
And if he loath his Uioletta; iudge by this.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.l: O sweetest Violet; I blush—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good figure,
Weare still that maiden blush, but still be mine.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: I seale my selfe thine owne, with both my hands,
In this true deede of gift: Gallants, heere stands
This Ladies Champion, at his foote Ile lye,
That dares touch her: who taintes my constancie,
I am no man for him, fight he with her,
And yeeld, for shee's a noble conquerer.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This combat shall not neede; for see, asham'd,
Of their rash vowes, these Gentlemen heere breake,
This storme; and doe with hands, what tongues should speake,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All friends?
All friends.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Puncke you may laugh at this,
Heer's trickes, but mouth Ile stop you with a kisse.
sp.stage: Enter Curuetto and Lazarillo, led by Blurt and the watch.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Roome, keep al the scabs back, for heer comes Lazarus.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Oh heer's our other spirits that walke i'th night,
Signior Curuetto, by complaint from her,
And by your writing heere, I reach the depth
Of your offence; they charge your climbing vp
To be to rob her: if so, then by law
You are to dye vnlesse she marrie you.

sp.speaker: Im.
sp.l: I, Fie fie, fie, I will be burnt to ashes first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: How? dye? or marie her? then call me Daw,
Marry her? shee's more common then the law,
For boyes to call me Oxe? noh, I am not drunke,
Ile play with her, but (hang her) wed no puncke.
I shall be a hoarie Courtier then indeede,
And haue a perilous head, then I were best.
Lye close, lye close, to hide my forked crest.
Noh; fye, fye, fye, hang me before the doore,
Where I was drown'd ere I marry with a whore.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Well Signior, for we rightly vnderstand,
From your accusers, how you stood her guest,
We pardon you and passe it as a iest:
And for the Spaniard sped so hardlie too,
Discharge him Blurt, Signior we pardon you.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Sir, hee's not to bee discharg'd, nor so to bee shot off, I haue put him into a new suite, and haue entred into him wich an action, he owes me two and thirtie shillings.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: It is thy honour to haue me dye in thy debt.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: It would be more honour to thee to pay me before thou dyest; twenty shillings of this debt came out of his nose.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Beare witnes great Duke, hee's paide twentie shillings.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Signior no, you cannot smoake me so; he tooke twenty shillings of it in a fewme, and the rest I charge him with for his lying.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lying (most pittifull Prince) was abhominable.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: He did lye (for the time) as well as any Knight of the Poaste did euer lye.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.p: I doe heere put off thy suite, and appeale; I warne thee to the Court of Conscience, and will pay thee by two pence a weeke, which I wil rake out of the hot embers of Tobacco ashes, and then trauaile on foote to the Indies for more golde, whose red cheekes I will kisse, and beate thee Blurt if thou watch for me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: There be many of your Countrymen in Ireland Signior, trauaile to them.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, I will fall no more into bogges.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Sirra, his debt, our selfe will satisfie.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Blurt (my Lord dare take your word for as much more.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: And since this heate of furie is all spent,
And Tragicke shapes meete Comicall euent:
Let this bright morning, merrily be crown'd
With daunces, banquets, and choyce Musickes sound.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
